title: Untitled
text: Quarto enables you to weave together content and executable code into a finished document. To learn more about Quarto see https://quarto.org.

title: Untitled
text:
Running Code
When you click the Render button a document will be generated that includes both content and the output of embedded code. You can embed code like this:

1 + 1

[1] 2


You can add options to executable code like this


[1] 4


The echo: false option disables the printing of code (only output is displayed).

title: Prerequisites
text:
In this meetup we will talk about GitHub Actions, and I will be presenting some practial examples. If anyone is interested in following along, is important to:

Have a GitHub account: https://github.com/Â  - itâ€™s free.
It would be nice to already know how to use Git and GitHub in RStudio.

title: Prerequisites
text:
What is Git? GitHub?
::: From: https://beamilz.com/posts/2022-06-05-creating-a-blog-with-quarto/en/#create-a-github-repository :::
If you have not used Git and GitHub with RStudio IDE before, I recommend you take some time to prepare your environment!
Here is a check-list you can use:

Install Git on your computer
Create a free account on GitHub
Install package usethis: install.packages("usethis")
Introduce yourself to Git:

usethis::use_git_config(
  # your name
  user.name = "Captain Marvel",
  # your email used in your GitHub account
  user.email = "awesomecaptain@gmail.com"
)

Create a GitHub PAT Token with usethis::create_github_token() (is like a password)
Store your token with gitcreds::gitcreds_set()
Restart your R Session (usually CTRL + SHIFT + F10 will do the work)
Use usethis::git_sitrep() to check if your name, email and PAT are configured. The most important thing to look for is: Personal access token for 'https://github.com': '<discovered>'.

title: Prerequisites
text:
Read more
Suggestions of supplemental material about using Git and GitHub in RStudio:

First Steps in Learning the Use of Git & GitHub in RStudio - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jN6tvgt3GK8
You can read detailed information about how to do this in the book Happy Git with R.

title: Prerequisites
section: Configuring Git and GitHub in RStudio
text:
Configuring Git and GitHub in RStudio

From: https://beamilz.com/posts/2022-06-05-creating-a-blog-with-quarto/en/#create-a-github-repository

If you have not used Git and GitHub with RStudio IDE before, I recommend you take some time to prepare your environment!
Here is a check-list you can use:

Install Git on your computer
Create a free account on GitHub
Install package usethis: install.packages("usethis")
Introduce yourself to Git:

usethis::use_git_config(
  # your name
  user.name = "Captain Marvel",
  # your email used in your GitHub account
  user.email = "awesomecaptain@gmail.com"
)

Create a GitHub PAT Token with usethis::create_github_token() (is like a password)
Store your token with gitcreds::gitcreds_set()
Restart your R Session (usually CTRL + SHIFT + F10 will do the work)
Use usethis::git_sitrep() to check if your name, email and PAT are configured. The most important thing to look for is: Personal access token for 'https://github.com': '<discovered>'.

text:
Configuring Git and GitHub in RStudio
If you have not used Git and GitHub with RStudio IDE before, I recommend you take some time to prepare your environment!
Here is a check-list you can use:

Install Git on your computer
Create a free account on GitHub
Install package usethis: install.packages("usethis")
Introduce yourself to Git:

usethis::use_git_config(
  # your name
  user.name = "Captain Marvel",
  # your email used in your GitHub account
  user.email = "awesomecaptain@gmail.com"
)

Create a GitHub PAT Token with usethis::create_github_token() (is like a password)
Store your token with gitcreds::gitcreds_set()
Restart your R Session (usually CTRL + SHIFT + F10 will do the work)
Use usethis::git_sitrep() to check if your name, email and PAT are configured. The most important thing to look for is: Personal access token for 'https://github.com': '<discovered>'.

text:
Run arbitrary R scripts


Scrape data from the internet
Run reports with RMarkdown or Quarto
Send emails
Save results
Deploy Shiny Apps.
.. And so on! Depends on what are your skills in R.

text:
Package development


Run devtools::check()
Run tests
Build and update documentation and website

title: Running code while weâ€™re sleeping
text:
Git and GitHub


Git is a Version Control System (VCS).
It is able to store the change history of all files inside a folder, which we call a repository.
It becomes important as your work is collaborative.
Git is software that you can install on your computer.

title: Running code while weâ€™re sleeping
text:
Git


Git is a Version Control System (VCS).
It is able to store the change history of all files inside a folder, which we call a repository.
It becomes important as your work is collaborative.
Git is software that you can install on your computer.

title: Running code while weâ€™re sleeping
text:
GitHub


GitHub is a service where you store and share Git repositories.
Used by millions of people in open or closed source projects.
Useful for collaborating with other programmers on data science projects.
There are alternatives such as GitLab and BitBucket.
GitHub is a website that you can access on the internet.
